I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will promote renewable energy, 
improve power grid stability, and support Mongolia’s energy policy through studies to transform 
the existing national power grid to a smart grid using innovative technologies and practices.1 
 
2.  The TA is included in the country operations business plan for Mongolia, 2020–2021 of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB).2 The TA is aligned with Mongolia’s Mid-term National Energy 
Policy (2018–2023).3 The TA will support the operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030 to 
mitigate climate change impacts and enhance environmental sustainability.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The Government of Mongolia’s target for renewable energy as a share of total energy 
generation is 20% by 2023 and 30% by 2030 (footnote 3). The target is in line with the submitted 
Nationally Determined Contribution under the Paris Agreement to reduce national greenhouse 
gas  emissions  and  mitigate  climate  change.5 To  achieve  its  targets,  the  government  has 
requested ADB to support a study on grid modernization using innovative technologies and 
solutions. ADB's Strategy 2030 supports using innovative technologies to tackle climate change. 
 
4.  The country's electricity management system (EMS) was installed in 2006 but has limited 
capability to implement timely dispatch of power and wholesale market financial settlement among 
power supply entities (power generation, transmission, and distribution companies) and large-
scale  consumers.  Its  supervisory  control  and data  acquisition  (SCADA)  system,  which  the 
National Dispatching Center (NDC) uses to monitor and control the energy grid, covers a limited 
number of substations and is segmented by region. 
 
5.  Furthermore, because Mongolia is a vast and sparsely populated landlocked country, the 
country's power transmission lines generally stretch long distances, exposing the grid to stability 
risks. The country’s large load centers are in the north, while the best wind power resources are 
in the south. Developing wind power generators with fluctuating output far from load centers would 
increase the risk of voltage instability. 
 
6.  NDC is Mongolia’s national power system operator and the owner of the existing EMS. 
NDC finds it challenging to maintain  power grid stability when output from fluctuating and 
intermittent renewable energy sources, such as solar photovoltaic and wind turbines, increases. 
These constraints make it difficult for Mongolia to achieve its renewable energy share targets. 
 
 
1 According to the country’s State Energy Sector Policy 2015-2030, smart energy system is expected to support 
achieving the policy targets such as the increase of energy efficiency and of renewable energy share by adopting 
innovation and advanced technology. 
2  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2020–2021. Manila. The TA first appeared in the business 
opportunities section of ADB’s website on 16 April 2019. 
3  Government of Mongolia. 2018. Mid-term National Energy Policy (2018–2023). Ulaanbaatar. 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
5  United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. 2016. Intended Nationally Determined Contribution 
Submission by Mongolia to the Ad Hoc Working Group on the Durban Platform for Enhanced Action. Bonn.

2 
7.  When power supply and demand are imbalanced, power grids are prone to large-scale 
blackouts. Therefore, Mongolia urgently needs to establish a smart energy system that integrates 
monitoring and control of the grid. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) adoption of innovation and advanced 
technology promoted, and energy sector efficiency increased; and (ii) greenhouse gas emissions 
reduced.6 The TA will have the following outcome: readiness for investments in a smart energy 
system using high-level technology (HLT)7 increased.8 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  The TA will undertake a feasibility study on adopting a smart energy system using HLT for 
Mongolia's power transmission network. 
 
10.  Output 1: Investment-ready smart energy system plan incorporating high-level 
technology for transmission grid developed. 
 
(i)  Assess the establishment of metering data management system (MDMS), which 
will  upgrade  and  expand  the  existing  automatic  meter-reading  system  for 
wholesale  energy  market  and  improve  the  accuracy  and  transparency  of 
transactions  among  power  utilities,  including  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution companies. The MDMS server will facilitate payments among power 
utilities  by  connecting  their  revenue-precision  meters  via  SCADA  and  other 
systems. MDMS is an HLT system.    
(ii)  Assess the impact of synchro-phasor-based wide area monitoring system (WAMS) 
that would expedite the restoration of power supply from the wide-spread blackout 
and reduce the possibility of future blackouts. WAMS is an HLT system.9 
(iii)  Propose a plan to expand the SCADA network  from the central energy system 
(CES)  to  the  other  regional  energy  systems.  NDC  will  establish  regional 
dispatching centers (RDCs) in the western, eastern, and southern regions to 
supplement the NDC. Recommend upgrades for the EMS to meet the evolving 
needs of the energy sector, and recommend the establishment of a backup control 
center and measures to counter cyber-security risk. 
(iv)  Design the scope of work for RDCs. 
(v)  Assess if existing policy and market related to grid flexibility need any modification 
to adopt the proposed smart energy system. 
(vi)  Prepare a feasibility study report that contains an Action Plan of Smart Energy for 
Mongolia (2020–2025) and an investment plan of smart energy system based on 
the above findings.  
(vii)  Prepare a due diligence report on the prioritized smart energy project which will be 
identified during the feasibility study. 
 
6  Government of Mongolia. 2015. State Energy Sector Policy 2015–2030. Ulaanbaatar; and United Nations Framework 
Convention on Climate Change. 2016. Paris Agreement-Status of Ratification. Paris. 
7  For the definition of High-level technology, see the link: https://www.adb.org/documents/high-level-technology 
8  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
9  Wide area monitoring system (WAMS) aims to improve the power grid stability, measuring the grid status with synchro 
phasor data.

3 
 
11.  Output 2: Capacity of National Dispatching Center to manage smart energy system 
enhanced. 
 
(i)  The TA will support hands-on training for NDC staff on the use of HLT such as MDMS, 
WAMS, and other smart energy technologies and practices. Capacity building would 
provide training of analysys of major events in the power system like cascading 
blackout, voltage stability, and harmonized protection relay settings, using analytical 
tool like DigSilent. The capacity building would also provide training on the assessment 
of suitable policy and the market design for the power system flexibility as well as 
proposed wholesale electricity market settlement practices using the recommended 
MDMS. The consultant will organize an international study tour to build the capacity of 
executing agency and implementing agency staff, focusing on HLT. 
(ii)  Organize domestic workshops to disseminate the study findings to energy sector 
stakeholders, including the Ministry of Energy (MOE), inviting resource persons for 
knowledge transfer of international best practice. 
(iii)  Explore measures to engage more female staff with smart energy system at the NDC. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.8 million, of which (i) $1.0 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the High-Level Technology Fund (HLTF);10 (ii) $0.5 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund (ACEF)11 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership 
Facility (CEFPF), both to be administered by ADB; The government will provide counterpart 
balance in-kind contributions (para15). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
13.  Eligible HLTF expenditures include but are not limited to consulting services, goods, 
works,  and  plants  for  project  identification  and  development,  project  preparation,  project 
implementation,  and  operation  (including  activities  such  as  survey,  conference,  seminars, 
workshops, travel, per diem, remuneration, resource person, report, communication, publications, 
pilot activities, capacity development, and research and policy advice activities related to HLT 
projects). The eligibility of knowledge transfer activities in a country outside of the recipient 
developing member country is subject to consultation with the donors committee and will be 
determined on a case-by-case basis.12 
 
14.  For the ACEF under the CEFPF, eligible expenditures include consulting services, training 
and workshops, and equipment. The following expenditures are not eligible: (i) vehicle purchases, 
(ii) salaries for civil servants, (iii) scholarships or internships, (iv) civil works and other related 
expenses, and (v) foreign training or study tour.13 
 
15.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office space, office 
supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, information and documents relevant for 
the implementation of the TA, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
 
10 Financing partner: the Government of Japan. 
11 Established by the Government of Japan. 
12 ADB. 2017. Implementation Guidelines for the High-Level Technology Fund. Manila. 
13 ADB. 2013. Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility Implementation Guidelines for the Asian Clean Energy 
Fund. Manila.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA, and recruit consultants to implement the two outputs. ADB’s 
Sustainable Infrastructure Division, East Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate 
consultants. A working committee comprising the Ministry of Energy, NDC, and National Power 
Transmission Grid Corporation (NPTG) will be established to coordinate TA implementation. The 
project  team  will  also  ensure  close  coordination  with  other  energy  sector  programs  and 
interventions in Mongolia. Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.14 The individual consultants, smart energy specialist (5 person-months), 
and power sector specialist (4 person-months) will be recruited to conduct a preliminary study in 
the most effective and efficient manner. An international consulting firm (36.75 person-months) 
will be recruited to conduct a feasibility study, focusing on the evaluation of the impact of HLT on 
to the proposed investment plan. Another international consulting firm (25 person-months) will be 
required to conduct the due diligence for the prioritized smart energy project for future lending 
pipeline. The ACEF will finance the due diligence, while the HTLF will fund the remaining 
consulting inputs. International consulting firms will be selected through the quality- and cost-
based selection method using the full technical proposal. The ratio of quality against cost will be 
90:10 to ensure the quality of the complex scope. While the main tasks will be undertaken by the 
international  consulting  firms,  resource  persons  may  be  recruited  as  expert  presenters  in 
 
14 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
workshops to introduce international best practices. Time-based contracts will be considered for 
the  engagement  of  individual  consultants  and  resource  persons.  Disbursements  will  be  in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
18.  Cofinancier requirements. TA implementation will follow the additional monitoring and 
reporting requirements specific to the HLTF (footnote 12) and the ACEF under the CEFPF 
(footnote 13). 
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the High-Level Technology Fund, and (ii) ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership 
Facility to the Government of Mongolia for Smart Energy System for Mongolia, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Investment-ready smart energy system plan incorporating high-level technology for 
transmission grid developed 
1.1  Recruit consultant to assess the system (Q4 2019–Q2 2020). 
1.2  Prepare feasibility study report (Q1 2021). 
1.3   Prepare due diligence report for the prioritized smart energy system project (Q3 2021). 
1.4   Organize workshops to disseminate the result (Q1 2020–Q3 2021). 
2.  Capacity of National Dispatching Center to manage smart energy system enhanced 
2.1  Engage consultants (Q4 2019–Q2 2020). 
2.2  Provide HLT capacity building to the executing agency and the implementing agencies, including 
workshops and study tour (Q1 2020–Q3 2021). 
2.3  Engage consultant to analyze ways to engage more women in jobs related to smart energy 
systems, including at the NDC (Q1 2020–Q3 2021).
